Award.AwardTitle: IGERT- Genetic Engineering and Society: The Case of Transgenic Pests

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) award supports the first graduate program in the world specifically training graduate students to understand, build, and assess impacts of transgenic organisms. The world recently witnessed the first open field release of a mosquito genetically engineered for suppressing transmission of a human disease. There is substantial debate regarding the appropriateness of this release and there are more complex transgenic pest strains being engineered for implementing Genetic Pest Management (GPM) of agricultural pests and invasive species. These developments evoke debates that continue to surround transgenic agricultural crops. Given this legacy, the future of GPM is likely to be determined by both social dynamics and technological advances.

Intellectual Merit: This IGERT integrates diverse disciplines, but it maintains the focus of trainees by studying a small set of species that are targets for GPM. Through a series of required IGERT courses, including one held in Latin America, all students receive core transdisciplinary training encompassing molecular biology, population genetics, ethics, communication, economics, and ecology. Each student specializes in one discipline and develops a dissertation with one or more substantial chapters centered on a target species. Broader Impacts: This IGERT will 1) improve methodologies for assessing and introducing new technologies, especially in poorer nations where many pests targeted for GPM are located; 2) evaluate a novel model for transdisciplinary graduate education; 3) provide integrative education to students from underrepresented groups in areas across the biological and social sciences; and 4) prepare Ph.D.s for careers requiring interdisciplinary skills and an understanding of global issues and cultures.

IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our IGERT created a diverse group of interactive students, trained in technologies used for manipulation of pest genomes as well as methods needed to assess the environmental and socio-cultural appropriateness of specific products of these manipulations. The very new technology for engineering pests to cause demise of natural populations or to change their characteristics to make them less of a pest is still years from implementation at a large scale. However, it is important to assess the potential ecological and societal implications of the products prior to their release into the wild. Our students have done just that.

            PhD students were recruited from within and beyond NC State University in three yearly cohorts. Each cohort was composed of students doing PhDs in the social sciences and biological science. Each cohort started in mid-July with a hands-on 2-3 week field course.

            The first cohort went to a city in the Peruvian Amazon to study whether and how genetically engineered mosquitoes could help in alleviating the problem there with dengue virus that is vectored by mosquitoes. The engineered mosquitoes could be designed to not transmit the virus and to have a mechanism that would spread the trait into the local population.

            The second cohort went to islands off the coast of California. The issue studied was whether mice could be engineered to pass on a trait that would skew the sex ratio toward all males and crash the populations of this invasive rodent that was harming endangered species on the islands.

            The final cohort went to Mexico to study if and how engineered agricultural pests could be used to limit damage by the native pests of maize. In addition to learning an immense amount about local biology and socioeconomic issues, the students in all of these cohorts developed close bonds that were maintained throughout their PhD programs.

            Once back at NC State, the students took three specific courses that formed the core of a new graduate minor at NC State in “Genetic Engineering and Society”. The courses ranged from genetics to sociology and ethics. Students who were specializing in an area of a course mentored the other students for whom the material was new and difficult.  Students in each cohort did a group project on the study system they started with on their field courses. These projects resulted in publications and/or a website. Students had the option of writing interdisciplinary research proposals for a final year of funding. Some of these resulted in publications. Each student had to have one thesis chapter related to the issues addressed by the IGERT. Some had an entire thesis on these issues.

            At this point we have trained 20 students, 5 of whom have graduated. Three of the 5 were immediately hired into tenure track academic jobs, one went on immediately into a job as a senior economist at the Research Triangle Institute, and one took a postdoc in his field. Other students are on track to finish soon. Some are interested in an academic path but many want to go into industry or government positions.

 


Last Modified: 08/01/2018
Modified by: Fred L Gould

PhD students were recruited from within and beyond NC State University in three yearly cohorts. Each cohort was composed of students doing PhDs in the social sciences and biological science. Each cohort started in mid-July with a hands-on 2-3 week field course. The first cohort went to a city in the Peruvian Amazon to study whether and how genetically engineered mosquitoes could help in alleviating the problem there with dengue virus that is vectored by mosquitoes. The engineered mosquitoes could be designed to not transmit the virus and to have a mechanism that would spread the trait into the local population. The second cohort went to islands off the coast of California. The issue studied was whether mice could be engineered to pass on a trait that would skew the sex ratio toward all males and crash the populations of this invasive rodent that was harming endangered species on the islands. In addition to learning an immense amount about local biology and socioeconomic issues, the students in all of these cohorts developed close bonds that were maintained throughout their PhD programs. Once back at NC State, the students took three specific courses that formed the core of a new graduate minor at NC State in "Genetic Engineering and Society". The courses ranged from genetics to sociology and ethics. Students who were specializing in an area of a course mentored the other students for whom the material was new and difficult. At this point we have trained 20 students, 5 of whom have graduated.
